_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Video cameras  installed around perimiter of the facility.
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Leprino Foods Company - Greeley plant complies with the prevention program level 3 requirements found in the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119). This program is organized into the following elements: 1)Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program wherever possible; 2) Training is provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process safety information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) A Process hazard analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and isperiodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot work permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire near the ammonia process; 9) The management of change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to the initial start and any restart of the system after modifications to ensure that impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency planning and response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's emergency plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Leprino Foods Company - Greeley facility complies with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.   All employees are informed of hazards in the workplace. Employees who work with potentially hazardous substances receive proper training in the handling of those substances. This facility has a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  There are also procedures in place to safely remove employees from areas in the unlikely event that a hazardous substance release were to occur, and to put in place emergency notification and response procedures.   





2. Facility and Regulated Substances



The Leprino Foods Company - Greeley plant's primary activities encompass cheese manufacturing, non-fat dry milk, and whey proteins. The plant is located in Greeley, CO. The sole regulated substance at this facility, anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7664-41-7), is used in a closed-loop refrigeration system for product cooling and human comfort (HVAC).  In order to protect its employees, the public and the environment, Leprino Foods has an integrated safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur. 





3. Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios



Off Site Consequence (OCA) data is available for review onsite at the Leprino Foods Company - Greeley facility.





4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Ammonia Specific Prevention



Leprino Foods has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA. The Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration system is also subject to the OSH

A PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The Leprino Foods Company - Greeley facility also has an emergency plan that addresses the response necessary for a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system. Because of the pungent odor of ammonia, any leak is easily detected. The engine room is also provided with ammonia detectors that sound an alarm if ammonia is detected. The refrigeration system is designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves. Further, refrigeration system operators have been trained and are knowledgeable in the safe operation of the refrigeration system.  In case of a release that could travel off the plant property, calls would be made to the Greeley Fire Department and the Weld County disaster services coordinator(s) or representatives to assist in the response. Other state and federal notifications would be made as required.





5. Five Year Accident History



This facility is a new design/build facility and this RMP submission is a first time submission, therefore there have been no reportable releases of ammonia.  





6. Emergency Planning and Response Program



This facility has procedures in place to respond to the release of a hazardous substance. Employees are trained according to their responsibilites (HAZMAT team onsite).  Coordination with the local fire department and/or local responding agencies is initiated during an emergency situation.





7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Leprino Foods Company - Greeley plant expects to improve safety performance by emphasizing all elements of the PSM/RMP program.  All recommendations during the Process Hazard Analysis were designed to improve the safety performance of the ammonia refrigeration process.  The PSM/RMP team expects to evaluate each recommendation in a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a relea
se and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
